abstract: Three boats carrying flood victims sank in a storm, raising to 41 the death toll in weeklong floods throughout Bangladesh, officials said today. Sixty people are missing after their boat sank Friday during a storm.
lead_paragraph: Three boats carrying flood victims sank in a storm, raising to 41 the death toll in weeklong floods throughout Bangladesh, officials said today. Sixty people are missing after their boat sank Friday during a storm.

headline.main: Bangladesh Flood Toll at 41
headline.print_headline: Bangladesh Flood Toll at 41

abstract: The head of this nation's military Government proclaimed himself President today and dissolved his Cabinet. The move appeared to be an attempt to consolidate his power before the presidential election that he has called for next May.   Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, 53 years old, who seized power in a nonviolent coup in 1982, less than a year after the slaying of President Ziaur Rahman, has made no secret of the fact that he intends to shed his army uniform and run for president in the May election.   He has formed his own political party, largely army-based, in anticipation of doing so. Justice A. F. M. Ahsanuddin Chowdhury, who had been the figurehead President in General Ershad's military regime, resigned today.
lead_paragraph: The head of this nation's military Government proclaimed himself President today and dissolved his Cabinet. The move appeared to be an attempt to consolidate his power before the presidential election that he has called for next May.

headline.main: BANGLADESH LEADER IN MILITARY REGIME ASSUMES PRESIDENCY
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH LEADER IN MILITARY REGIME ASSUMES PRESIDENCY

byline.original: By William K. Stevens, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The village of Tingaon, south of here, looks idyllic and abundantly prosperous in the warmth of a spring afternoon. Its bamboo huts nestle atop a small, man-made mesa, built to keep them safe when monsoon rains flood the green rice fields that stretch in every direction.   But when the villagers themselves appear, they look anything but prosperous. It is possible to count the ribs of many of them. Only about one in four in a crowd of about 60 who gather to greet visitors is an adult, and most of them say they are hungry most of the time.
lead_paragraph: The village of Tingaon, south of here, looks idyllic and abundantly prosperous in the warmth of a spring afternoon. Its bamboo huts nestle atop a small, man-made mesa, built to keep them safe when monsoon rains flood the green rice fields that stretch in every direction.

headline.main: HUNGRY BANGLADESH THREATENS TO BURST ITS SEAMS
headline.print_headline: HUNGRY BANGLADESH THREATENS TO BURST ITS SEAMS

byline.original: By William K. Stevens, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The army general who led a coup against the Government of Bangladesh 18 months ago came to rural southeast Texas today and watched how long-grain paddy rice was sorted, milled and parboiled here at the highly automated El Campo Rice Milling Company.    If it seemed odd that a man of the sword should be interested in agriculture, it was not surprising to those who understand the political realities of Bangladesh, an impoverished land where a poor harvest or food shortages can lead to enormous turmoil.   ''We are trying to be self-sufficient, so we are looking at everything to find better technology to produce better rice and more rice,'' said the leader, Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammad Ershad, President of the martial law Government.   General Ershad spoke at the Wharton County Electric Cooperative in nearby El Campo, where he and his entourage were treated to a Texas lunch of barbecued beef, beans and rice. They appeared to enjoy the food; his Texas hosts may been been rural folk, but they were diplomatically savvy enough to omit the pork ribs for the Islamic guests.
lead_paragraph: The army general who led a coup against the Government of Bangladesh 18 months ago came to rural southeast Texas today and watched how long-grain paddy rice was sorted, milled and parboiled here at the highly automated El Campo Rice Milling Company.

headline.main: TEXAS RICE COUNTRY SALUTES A BANGLADESH GENERAL
headline.print_headline: TEXAS RICE COUNTRY SALUTES A BANGLADESH GENERAL

abstract: The weathered low concrete pillars marking the boundary between India and Bangladesh are difficult to spot from the bumpy dirt road that runs along the frontier.   There are no border patrols in sight, no fences, no walls. A oneminute walk through harvested rice fields where farmers rest in the shade of bamboo thickets while watching their cattle and a visitor is in Bangladesh.   It is that simple to cross the 300-mile-long frontier in parts of the northeastern states of Meghalaya and Assam. Local officials and Assamese activists say hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants have crossed into India here.
lead_paragraph: The weathered low concrete pillars marking the boundary between India and Bangladesh are difficult to spot from the bumpy dirt road that runs along the frontier.

headline.main: INDIA BORDER IS NO BARRIER TO BANGLADESH MIGRANTS
headline.print_headline: INDIA BORDER IS NO BARRIER TO BANGLADESH MIGRANTS

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: FOREIGN POPULATION AND FOREIGN DESCENT GROUPS

byline.original: By Sanjoy Hazarika, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The Government announced today that elections would be held next month in the troubled northeastern state of Assam, and policemen there reportedly arrested about 20 student leaders of a movement that has vowed to block all voting.   These developments followed the collapse of negotiations here between Government officials and student representatives, who are demanding the deportation from Assam of millions of immigrants, most of them from neighboring Bangladesh. The students say that the Assamese, who are primarily Hindu, might be overwhelmed by the flood of immigrants, who are largely Moslem.
lead_paragraph: The Government announced today that elections would be held next month in the troubled northeastern state of Assam, and policemen there reportedly arrested about 20 student leaders of a movement that has vowed to block all voting.

headline.main: INDIA SETS A VOTE IN STATE OF ASSAM
headline.print_headline: INDIA SETS A VOTE IN STATE OF ASSAM

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

abstract: Outbreaks of cholera in three areas have killed more than 500 people in the last six weeks, a newspaper reported today.   New Nation, an independent English- language daily, said the disease killed 280 people in Manikganj, a town 27 miles west of Dhaka, 121 in Chittagong, a port, and 100 on Sandwip Island northeast of Chittagong.
lead_paragraph: Outbreaks of cholera in three areas have killed more than 500 people in the last six weeks, a newspaper reported today.

headline.main: Cholera Reportedly Kills 500 In 3 Outbreaks in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: Cholera Reportedly Kills 500 In 3 Outbreaks in Bangladesh

abstract: Nearly a dozen years have passed since Bangladesh won its war of independence from Pakistan with the help of India, and in that time the volatile Bengali nation has been unable to achieve lasting political stability.   ''That is our great misfortune,'' said a Bengali journalist here in the capital, where everything is under military rule and signs in the hotels remind guests of the nightly curfew.   Bangladesh, many here say, must have political peace so recent gains in food production, economic development and birth-control programs can be stepped up. As things stand, the country is just about able to keep its very low standard of living from sinking lower.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a dozen years have passed since Bangladesh won its war of independence from Pakistan with the help of India, and in that time the volatile Bengali nation has been unable to achieve lasting political stability.

headline.main: IN BANGLADESH, THE PATH TO STABILITY IS UPHILL
headline.print_headline: IN BANGLADESH, THE PATH TO STABILITY IS UPHILL

byline.original: By William K. Stevens, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The people of Assam, one of India's most remote and troubled states, are being asked over the next seven days to choose a new State Legislature and 12 members of the national Parliament. But violence born of ethnic fears and hatreds is keeping both voters and candidates away from the polls.   This weekend, for example, only smoldering shells remained of many mud and thatch huts in the devastated village of Chamaria, 60 miles from this state capital. The village had been attacked for six hours by a spear-wielding, largely Moslem mob. The police say that at least seven people were killed at Chamaria and that the death toll is rising everywhere.
lead_paragraph: The people of Assam, one of India's most remote and troubled states, are being asked over the next seven days to choose a new State Legislature and 12 members of the national Parliament. But violence born of ethnic fears and hatreds is keeping both voters and candidates away from the polls.

headline.main: ETHNIC HATRED BOILS OVER IN AN INDIAN BORDER STATE
headline.print_headline: ETHNIC HATRED BOILS OVER IN AN INDIAN BORDER STATE

byline.original: By Sanjoy Hazarika, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Mohinder Bhambra poured a cup of creamy sweet tea for the young man seated in his small living room and in a torrent of Punjabi explained why he planned to cast a ballot for the Liberal candidate in Thursday's general election.   ''He is one of our own people and that is the way it should be,'' the old man told his guest, a campaign worker for the Liberal-Social Democratic Party alliance in the Ealing-Southall constituency of London. ''And at the temple, the priest said we should all vote for him, that it is important for us to do so.''   The young man smiled at the response and duly noted in a book he carried listing all the registered voters in the ward that the Bhambra household could be counted on to cast three votes for Maurice Nadeen, a London lawyer born in India 52 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Mohinder Bhambra poured a cup of creamy sweet tea for the young man seated in his small living room and in a torrent of Punjabi explained why he planned to cast a ballot for the Liberal candidate in Thursday's general election.

headline.main: BRITISH NONWHITES SEEK BIGGER VOICE
headline.print_headline: BRITISH NONWHITES SEEK BIGGER VOICE

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: FOREIGN POPULATION AND FOREIGN DESCENT GROUPS

byline.original: By Jon Nordheimer, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Fifty years ago, in the first days of the agency that was to remold the Tennessee River Valley, all the cities and towns there were deep in the craw of the Great Depression.   In Decatur, Ala., for example, that was the year, 1933, when the largest industry in town, which had employed 2,000 people, sank to its knees and closed. A much smaller operation went bankrupt, then another and another. Seven of the eight banks in the county folded.  Cotton was selling for 5 cents a pound and land was selling for the amount of tax owed. Children had empty stomachs, parents had vacant eyes.   The per capita income in the region was $168 that year, about 45 percent of the national average. The birth rate was about a third above the national average. About 30 percent of the residents in some areas of the valley had malaria. More than half the three million people lived on farms, and half of them were sharecroppers. About 97 percent of the farms had no electricity. Fires burned about 10 percent of the forests each year, and floods ripped along the rivers. About 7 million of the region's 12 million cleared acres were severely eroded.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, in the first days of the agency that was to remold the Tennessee River Valley, all the cities and towns there were deep in the craw of the Great Depression.

headline.main: T.V.A., AT 50, DRAFTING NEW ROLE IN REGION'S FUTURE
headline.print_headline: T.V.A., AT 50, DRAFTING NEW ROLE IN REGION'S FUTURE

byline.original: By Wendell Rawls Jr., Special To the New York Times

abstract:
WEST LONG BRANCH MORE THAN 110 of New Jersey's top high school students have spent this hot July on the Monmouth College campus here, pondering problems that confront the state and the world.

The young men and women are enrolled in the first Governor's School for Gifted Students. The purpose of the four-week, tuition-free program on public policy, which began July 2, is to give students an opportunity to study contemporary questions beyond the high school level and to encourage them to grow as responsible, participating citizens.

''Governor's schools in several other states in the last few years have emphasized advanced-placement courses for college-bound students,'' said James P. Keen, co-director of the school with his wife, Cheryl. ''We wanted to create a new theme.

headline.main: A 'FIRST' FOR GIFTED STUDENTS
headline.print_headline: A 'FIRST' FOR GIFTED STUDENTS

abstract: A report issued today by the National Academy of Sciences says that the coming warming of the earth caused by a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is ''cause for concern'' but that there is sufficient time to prepare for its impact.    The academy's report follows by three days a report by the Environmental Protection Agency on the warming phenomenon, known as the greenhouse effect. The two reports are similar in their findings, but the environmental agency called for steps to begin now to deal with the expected changes in world temperature and climate.   Tonight President Reagan's science adviser, George A. Keyworth 3d, sharply criticized the E.P.A. report and praised the National Academy's. He called the environmental agency's report ''unwarranted and unnecessarily alarmist.''
lead_paragraph: A report issued today by the National Academy of Sciences says that the coming warming of the earth caused by a buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is ''cause for concern'' but that there is sufficient time to prepare for its impact.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: SCIENCES, NATIONAL ACADEMY OF, AND NATIONAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

byline.original: By Philip Shabecoff , Special To the New York Times

abstract: THE PRICE OF POWER Kissinger in the Nixon White House.  By Seymour M. Hersh.  698 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.   SEYMOUR M. HERSH'S book could be called the Kissinger antimemoirs.  ''The Price of Power'' is a colossal effort to show that the image of mastery and public service conveyed by Henry Kissinger's own volumes is just one more skillful deception and that the unseemly aspects of policy making or the occasional miscalculations and mistakes acknowledged by the former National Security Adviser and Secretary of State actually constitute the essence of the Nixon-Kissinger era.   Mr. Hersh, an award-winning former reporter for The New York Times, has spent years stalking his prey. He has, he tells us, held more than 1,000 interviews. Many former officials have shown or given him their notes or hitherto unpublished documents; he has also read and compared the innumerable memoirs written about one of the most controversial and savage periods of modern American history.
lead_paragraph: THE PRICE OF POWER Kissinger in the Nixon White House. By Seymour M. Hersh. 698 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

headline.main: THE KISSINGER ANTIMEMOIRS
headline.print_headline: THE KISSINGER ANTIMEMOIRS

abstract: DHAKA, Bangladesh THE man staggered as he walked in and would have collapsed on the floor had a friend not been holding him up. Soon he was stretched out on a cot in a long, spotless, wardlike room that held perhaps 125 similarly stricken people, more than half of them children who appeared to be less than 5 years old.   Pale and sunken-eyed, some of the children whimpered or cried as their mothers, wrapped in gaily colored Bengali saris, ministered to them, but most were silent.   No cyclone or war was responsible. All were victims of a medical disaster of gigantic proportions and lethal powers. It is not the plague, malaria or yellow fever. It is simple, miserable, inelegant diarrhea, the most widespread and pervasive health problem in underdeveloped nations, and the biggest killer of children on the earth.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh THE man staggered as he walked in and would have collapsed on the floor had a friend not been holding him up. Soon he was stretched out on a cot in a long, spotless, wardlike room that held perhaps 125 similarly stricken people, more than half of them children who appeared to be less than 5 years old.

headline.print_headline: DIARRHEA PERSISTS AS SCOURGE OF THIRD WORLD

abstract: Like countless others who live in poverty across the country, the three children of Jerry and Betty Elkins know all too well what it is like to sit down to meager meals.   ''We usually have bread and gravy the last few days of the month,'' Mr. Elkins, who is 27 years old, said while waiting for a handout of Federal surplus food at Guyan Valley High School. ''This cheese and butter will really come in handy at our house.''   The Elkinses glanced at their children, ages 5, 6 and 7, as they talked about trying to stave off hunger in one of the most economically depressed areas of the country.
lead_paragraph: Like countless others who live in poverty across the country, the three children of Jerry and Betty Elkins know all too well what it is like to sit down to meager meals.

abstract: For Haiti, $26 million for energy resources. For the Central African Republic, $11 million for education programs. For Bangladesh, $110 million for food imports.   Those are some of the loans recently made by an affiliate of the World Bank that makes interest-free loans to the world's poorest countries for as long as 50 years. And loans of that size could become less frequent if United States proposals to cut back on the agency's lending pool are accepted.
lead_paragraph: For Haiti, $26 million for energy resources. For the Central African Republic, $11 million for education programs. For Bangladesh, $110 million for food imports.

headline.main: DISCORD ON AID TO POOR LANDS
headline.print_headline: DISCORD ON AID TO POOR LANDS

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development

abstract: In the 19th century Christian missionaries from the West traveled to India's northeast region seeking converts among the tough hill tribes.   Some were slain by tribesmen; others were struck down by a range of tropical diseases, including malaria and cholera. Yet the handful of American Baptists, Welsh Presbyterians, Irish Roman Catholics and Italian Jesuits persevered, tramping through jungles of pine and teak to carry their message to villages perched on steep hills.   Nearly 200 years later the foreign missionaries have been eased out of the politically sensitive northeast by the Indian Government, but their work of evangelizing and winning new converts is being continued by Indians who are running the large network of educational institutions, health centers and churches started by the pioneers.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century Christian missionaries from the West traveled to India's northeast region seeking converts among the tough hill tribes.

headline.main: IN HILLS OF EAST INDIA, A CHRISTIAN VISION SURVIVES
headline.print_headline: IN HILLS OF EAST INDIA, A CHRISTIAN VISION SURVIVES

byline.original: By Sanjoy Hazarika, Special To the New York Times

abstract: As public awareness of the disease known as AIDS has grown in the last few months, a picture has begun to emerge of the emotional and physical agony of those afflicted and of the fear, among homosexuals and about homosexuals, that has spread around the country at a rate much faster than the disease itself.   In New York, a restaurant owner reflects on the way his lover, shunned by hospitals and airlines and then by undertakers, died this winter of the ailment, acquired immune deficiency syndrome.   In Denver, a woman calls to ask how she should fumigate an apartment she bought from a homosexual.In Houston, some people refuse to donate blood lest they contract AIDS from the needles at the blood bank.  In New Orleans, a club owner sees a turn toward monogamy, a retreat from the casual, anonymous sex that has characterized ''the gay life style'' for many homosexuals.
lead_paragraph: As public awareness of the disease known as AIDS has grown in the last few months, a picture has begun to emerge of the emotional and physical agony of those afflicted and of the fear, among homosexuals and about homosexuals, that has spread around the country at a rate much faster than the disease itself.

headline.main: AIDS SPREADS PAIN AND FEAR AMONG ILL AND HEALTHY ALIKE
headline.print_headline: AIDS SPREADS PAIN AND FEAR AMONG ILL AND HEALTHY ALIKE

abstract: THE signs and sights and smells of the ''new'' Flushing poke out unexpectedly from among the small haberdashers, hardware and dry-goods stores and gift shops. Bharat, Ku Hwa, Mi-Mi, Shamiana, Sam Bok, Se-Ho Trading Company read the names of the food shops along Main, Union and Prince Streets and on the smaller side streets that cut through them. The word ''Seoul'' has been carefully lettered in front of the name of the Little Angels Department Store on Main Street, bestowing upon it a new Asian identity like that of many Flushing stores.    More and more, the shopkeepers are Asian in what was once one of many suburblike, homogeneously white commercial centers in the city's ''borough of homes.'' For them, and for many non- Asians as well, this area in Queens has become an exciting and exotic gastronomic mecca.   You can smell the paprika, fennel, sesame oil and mango chutney, and the pungency of the spicy, hot Korean salad called kimchee brings water to the eyes. The fruit and vegetable stands have stacks of lotus and taro roots, bok choy and choy sum, dried black mushrooms and cuttlefish alongside the fresh fruits and vegetables, and in the Sam Bok market on Main Street, Hono Pak will sell you five-feet-long sheets of dried seaweed and bottles of Mackoly, one brand of natural Korean rice wine.
lead_paragraph: THE signs and sights and smells of the ''new'' Flushing poke out unexpectedly from among the small haberdashers, hardware and dry-goods stores and gift shops. Bharat, Ku Hwa, Mi-Mi, Shamiana, Sam Bok, Se-Ho Trading Company read the names of the food shops along Main, Union and Prince Streets and on the smaller side streets that cut through them. The word ''Seoul'' has been carefully lettered in front of the name of the Little Angels Department Store on Main Street, bestowing upon it a new Asian identity like that of many Flushing stores.

headline.main: FLUSHING: A NEW CENTER FOR ASIAN MARKETS AND FOOD
headline.print_headline: FLUSHING: A NEW CENTER FOR ASIAN MARKETS AND FOOD

abstract: Jenna, a cousin of a foreign worker in Saudi Arabia, says she does not know how old she is, or exactly how long ago she came to this country from Pakistan. She does know that she has borne nine children, all of whom died. This year - ''Thanks be to God,'' she said - she had a son, whom she proudly displayed.    Jenna, 15 other adults in her extended family and their 27 children live in the heart of Jidda in a makeshift concrete shelter with a sand floor and a tin and cardboard roof.
lead_paragraph: Jenna, a cousin of a foreign worker in Saudi Arabia, says she does not know how old she is, or exactly how long ago she came to this country from Pakistan. She does know that she has borne nine children, all of whom died. This year - ''Thanks be to God,'' she said - she had a son, whom she proudly displayed.

headline.main: A STOIC FOREIGN WORK FORCE FILLS SAUDI JOBS
headline.print_headline: A STOIC FOREIGN WORK FORCE FILLS SAUDI JOBS

byline.original: By Judith Miller, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Skeletons are still scattered over the dry, flat rice field where more than 1,000 men, women and children were slaughtered last month by a mob of tribespeople who attacked them with guns, spears and bows and arrows.   Residents and local officials said many of the bodies of people killed near this predominantly Moslem town in Assam State had been dug from their shallow graves by scavenging dogs, foxes and vultures. The drone of flies and the stench of rotting flesh fill the air.  Hamlets are silent and deserted, their mud-and-straw huts destroyed by fire.
lead_paragraph: Skeletons are still scattered over the dry, flat rice field where more than 1,000 men, women and children were slaughtered last month by a mob of tribespeople who attacked them with guns, spears and bows and arrows.

headline.main: IN ASSAM, THE KILLINGS ABATE BUT THE FEARS LINGER
headline.print_headline: IN ASSAM, THE KILLINGS ABATE BUT THE FEARS LINGER

byline.original: By Sanjoy Hazarika, Special To the New York Times

abstract: At the height of the twin crises of Lebanon and Grenada, a White House official telephoned a Washington editor and, reversing the normal process, asked the editor how his newspaper was reacting to the Administration's actions on both fronts.    On Capitol Hill, a member of Congress was given regular summaries of constituents' telephone calls to his district office in California to keep him up to the minute on public reaction.   At cocktail parties and dinners around town, the fighting around Beirut and St. Georges was nearly the sole topic of discussion.   Information, Washington's stock in trade on a day-to-day basis, becomes, at times of crisis, an essential commodity sought by everyone. This week, it seemed that all kinds of Washingtonians - lobbyists, members of Congress and business executives - all had become reporters. They were after the ''inside'' stuff on how and by whom decisions were being made at the top.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the twin crises of Lebanon and Grenada, a White House official telephoned a Washington editor and, reversing the normal process, asked the editor how his newspaper was reacting to the Administration's actions on both fronts.

headline.main: 2 TOPICS: GRENADA AND BEIRUT, BEIRUT AND GRENADA
headline.print_headline: 2 TOPICS: GRENADA AND BEIRUT, BEIRUT AND GRENADA

abstract: Although the violence that surged through Assam and the tension that still grips the troubled northeastern state have genuinely and profoundly shaken much of India, there has been no rush to judgment, no calls for inquiries and few demands for the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to resign.   In fact, correspondents reached by telephone today in the state capital, Gauhati, said all adversaries in the tragedy had sought to avoid responsibility and had refrained from blaming one another for the more than three weeks of violence, which erupted as a mostly Hindu political movement led by students sought to prevent state election balloting in which Moslem immigrants were also allowed to vote. Officials say more than 1,000 people died in the attacks on Moslem settlements by Assamese.   There have been no reported arrests. The leaders of the movement, which has demanded that the immigrants, mostly from Bangladesh, be removed from electoral rolls and deported, have condemned the violence in ambiguous terms while praising those who boycotted and protested the elections. Two divisions of paramilitary troops are maintaining low profiles. Civil servants brought in from other states to supervise the vote are reported to be anxious to go home.
lead_paragraph: Although the violence that surged through Assam and the tension that still grips the troubled northeastern state have genuinely and profoundly shaken much of India, there has been no rush to judgment, no calls for inquiries and few demands for the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to resign.

headline.main: News Analysis
headline.kicker: IN DELHI, SHOCK BUT NO RUSH TO JUDGMENT
headline.print_headline: IN DELHI, SHOCK BUT NO RUSH TO JUDGMENT; News Analysis

byline.original: By Michael T. Kaufman, Special To the New York Times

abstract: FOR years, Richard J. Daronco recalled last week, ''I used to wave at my friends going to the Pelham railroad station as I headed for the Hutchinson River Parkway and White Plains,'' where he was a State Supreme Court Justice.   ''But last Tuesday,'' he said, ''I was on the platform with them,'' on the way to New York City.   That was Judge Daronco's first day as deputy chief administrative judge of the state's Office of Court Administration. He was starting work just one week after being asked to fill the job, one of the highest judicial posts in the state. He will be responsible for all major trial courts outside New York City - ''roughly 450,'' he said, ''with a budget of about $185 million a year.''
lead_paragraph: FOR years, Richard J. Daronco recalled last week, ''I used to wave at my friends going to the Pelham railroad station as I headed for the Hutchinson River Parkway and White Plains,'' where he was a State Supreme Court Justice.

headline.main: JUDGE DARONCO ASSUMES STATE POST
headline.print_headline: JUDGE DARONCO ASSUMES STATE POST

abstract: BY definition, Off Off Broadway is a floating festival of diverse theatrical events, offering something for every taste. This weekend in particular, the scene is alive with promising entertainments. The emphasis is very much on spectacle, but in typical, experimental fashion, the spectacle can be an extravagant musical drawn from the Biblical plagues, Shakespeare transplanted to ancient China or a trio of inspired tomfools. And to even the score, there are new plays by very young dramatists and a restorative revival of a drama by Tennessee Williams. Two prolific theaters are showcasing a range of work by favorite sons and daughters. In the vast expanse of La Mama Annex is a musical called ''The Plagues,'' written by Eve Merriam and Tom O'Horgan, and directed by Mr. O'Horgan. In residence on other La Mama stages are Paul Zimet's Talking Band, doing an ensemble play with music titled ''Hot Lunch Apostles,'' and Harris Yulin, a Broadway star, playing the title buncombe artist in Richard Ploetz's ''Barnum's Last Life.'' At the nearby Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, at 10th Street, Leonard Melfi, a graduate of both La Mama and Theater for the New City, is showcasing a new epic musical, ''Rosetti's Apologies,'' while on another New City stage, Stuart Sherman is demonstrating his one-man, world-in-a-suitcase art with a performance piece called ''13 Spectacle'' (tickets for both $4; information: 254-1109).
lead_paragraph: BY definition, Off Off Broadway is a floating festival of diverse theatrical events, offering something for every taste. This weekend in particular, the scene is alive with promising entertainments. The emphasis is very much on spectacle, but in typical, experimental fashion, the spectacle can be an extravagant musical drawn from the Biblical plagues, Shakespeare transplanted to ancient China or a trio of inspired tomfools. And to even the score, there are new plays by very young dramatists and a restorative revival of a drama by Tennessee Williams. Two prolific theaters are showcasing a range of work by favorite sons and daughters. In the vast expanse of La Mama Annex is a musical called ''The Plagues,'' written by Eve Merriam and Tom O'Horgan, and directed by Mr. O'Horgan. In residence on other La Mama stages are Paul Zimet's Talking Band, doing an ensemble play with music titled ''Hot Lunch Apostles,'' and Harris Yulin, a Broadway star, playing the title buncombe artist in Richard Ploetz's ''Barnum's Last Life.'' At the nearby Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, at 10th Street, Leonard Melfi, a graduate of both La Mama and Theater for the New City, is showcasing a new epic musical, ''Rosetti's Apologies,'' while on another New City stage, Stuart Sherman is demonstrating his one-man, world-in-a-suitcase art with a performance piece called ''13 Spectacle'' (tickets for both $4; information: 254-1109).

headline.main: SURPRISES ARE NO SURPRISE ON OFF OFF BROADWAY
headline.print_headline: SURPRISES ARE NO SURPRISE ON OFF OFF BROADWAY

abstract: From a slender minaret of the Id Kah Mosque, a loudspeaker summoned the faithful to evening prayer.  A street vendor removed his cloth shoes, knelt on a piece of cardboard under a poplar tree and pressed his forehead to the ground in the southwestward direction of Mecca. Inside the rambling mosque in this heavily Moslem city in western China, a row of other worshipers facing the whitewashed wall took up the affirmation of God's greatness - ''Allah akhbar!''   Daily prayer, one of the five pillars of the Moslem faith, goes on today in the world's most populous atheistic country. After harsh but ultimately unsuccessful persecution by Maoist radicals, the authorities have allowed Islam to flourish and become China's most active religion. 13 Million Moslems   Statistics from last year's nationwide census indicated that China has about 13 million ethnic Moslems, more than the combined populations of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.  Unofficial estimates put the number closer to 20 million.
lead_paragraph: From a slender minaret of the Id Kah Mosque, a loudspeaker summoned the faithful to evening prayer. A street vendor removed his cloth shoes, knelt on a piece of cardboard under a poplar tree and pressed his forehead to the ground in the southwestward direction of Mecca. Inside the rambling mosque in this heavily Moslem city in western China, a row of other worshipers facing the whitewashed wall took up the affirmation of God's greatness - ''Allah akhbar!''

headline.main: ISLAM, AFTER PERSECUTIONS, REBOUNDS IN CHINA
headline.print_headline: ISLAM, AFTER PERSECUTIONS, REBOUNDS IN CHINA

byline.original: By Christopher S. Wren, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Maung Kown beckons a pair of visitors back into his simple pony cab at the end of a hot Burmese day of touring. Sunset nears, signaling the start of a daily pilgrimage. Settling into the bouncy rhythm and clatter of the pony's unhurried gait, the foreigners are conveyed along Pagan's dusty plain to a tall pagoda. The driver collects all footwear and sends his passengers up its warm stone steps.  Once they are at the top, the light waning, the scorched brown earth begins to grow coppery. Whitewashed columns and walls take on burning hues and even plain brick is fired brilliant oranges and reds. After the sun disappears, fluorescent bars blink on at the pagoda's stupas, or towers, and the sky glows 30 minutes more in a charged but serene display. Suddenly, the seemingly tired, ancient landscape is suffused with a sense of renewed inner life.
lead_paragraph: Maung Kown beckons a pair of visitors back into his simple pony cab at the end of a hot Burmese day of touring. Sunset nears, signaling the start of a daily pilgrimage. Settling into the bouncy rhythm and clatter of the pony's unhurried gait, the foreigners are conveyed along Pagan's dusty plain to a tall pagoda. The driver collects all footwear and sends his passengers up its warm stone steps. Once they are at the top, the light waning, the scorched brown earth begins to grow coppery. Whitewashed columns and walls take on burning hues and even plain brick is fired brilliant oranges and reds. After the sun disappears, fluorescent bars blink on at the pagoda's stupas, or towers, and the sky glows 30 minutes more in a charged but serene display. Suddenly, the seemingly tired, ancient landscape is suffused with a sense of renewed inner life.

headline.main: IN BURMA, ORDINARY IS BRILLIANT
headline.print_headline: IN BURMA, ORDINARY IS BRILLIANT

abstract: I was riding down a graveled highway in Tibet one chilly summer afternoon and had just reached the continental squeeze, the invisible line north of the Himalayas where the Indian subcontinent collided with Asia 50 million years ago.   There is no marker and I did not know until later, when a friendly geologist pointed to the place on a map, that the line crosses the road between Gyangze and Xigaze.   About the time our Japanese station wagon crossed the squeeze, one of my companions pointed out the left window. I looked, and there in the ditch, among the boulders and fossils of two continents, stood a naked man. He grinned and waved with the self-assured aplomb of a Manhattan street kid.
lead_paragraph: I was riding down a graveled highway in Tibet one chilly summer afternoon and had just reached the continental squeeze, the invisible line north of the Himalayas where the Indian subcontinent collided with Asia 50 million years ago.

headline.main: JOURNEY TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD
headline.print_headline: JOURNEY TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD

abstract: WHEN HE ROSE TO SPEAK, THE general was still wearing his cap, with the full complement of ornamental braid due his rank. Solemnly, he gave his undergraduate audience a rigid salute. The white, rosy-cheeked expressions turned up to him could not have been more earnest had they been in church. And the general easily slipped into an evangelist's role, depicting a conflict between forces of light and darkness. The former, it went without saying, were well represented in this lecture hall at the University of the Orange Free State in Bloemfontein, an Afrikaans-language citadel not noted for its tolerance of wayward ideas. The forces of darkness were the ''terrorists,'' black South Africans manipulated by the ''dragon'' of international Communism. It was exactly what might have been expected in Bloemfontein, except for one conspicuous detail: The general, Xhanti Charles Sebe, Director of State Security of the supposedly independent ''homeland'' of Ciskei, was black.  More than pigmentation made him a surprising figure. A handful of young Afrikaners in the hall seemed uneasily aware that here was a black man who surpassed them in ideological commitment; from their point of view, he was almost too good to be true. The coiled energy and enthusiasm in the man came out in a gravelly voice and staccato articulation. When he spoke of ''the devilish, destructive actions of trained terrorists,'' he squeezed off each syllable like a retaliatory shot.
lead_paragraph: WHEN HE ROSE TO SPEAK, THE general was still wearing his cap, with the full complement of ornamental braid due his rank. Solemnly, he gave his undergraduate audience a rigid salute. The white, rosy-cheeked expressions turned up to him could not have been more earnest had they been in church. And the general easily slipped into an evangelist's role, depicting a conflict between forces of light and darkness. The former, it went without saying, were well represented in this lecture hall at the University of the Orange Free State in Bloemfontein, an Afrikaans-language citadel not noted for its tolerance of wayward ideas. The forces of darkness were the ''terrorists,'' black South Africans manipulated by the ''dragon'' of international Communism. It was exactly what might have been expected in Bloemfontein, except for one conspicuous detail: The general, Xhanti Charles Sebe, Director of State Security of the supposedly independent ''homeland'' of Ciskei, was black. More than pigmentation made him a surprising figure. A handful of young Afrikaners in the hall seemed uneasily aware that here was a black man who surpassed them in ideological commitment; from their point of view, he was almost too good to be true. The coiled energy and enthusiasm in the man came out in a gravelly voice and staccato articulation. When he spoke of ''the devilish, destructive actions of trained terrorists,'' he squeezed off each syllable like a retaliatory shot.
